segment.source: Take Inventory of an Image or Component Using DISM
segment.target: Take Inventory of an Image or Component Using DISM

segment.source: Take Inventory of an Image or Component Using DISM
segment.target: Take Inventory of an Image or Component Using DISM

segment.source: Take Inventory of an Image or Component Using DISM
segment.target: Take Inventory of an Image or Component Using DISM

segment.source: You can take an inventory of what drivers, packages, and other files and settings are included in a Windows image.
segment.target: You can take an inventory of what drivers, packages, and other files and settings are included in a Windows image.

segment.source: To do so, use Deployment Image Servicing and Management (DISM) servicing commands.
segment.target: To do so, use Deployment Image Servicing and Management (DISM) servicing commands.

segment.source: You must mount an offline image from a WIM or VHD file before you can take inventory of or service a specific Windows image.
segment.target: You must mount an offline image from a WIM or VHD file before you can take inventory of or service a specific Windows image.

segment.source: For more information, see Mount and Modify a Windows Image Using DISM.
segment.target: For more information, see Mount and Modify a Windows Image Using DISM.

segment.source: You can use image commands to list the information about a specific Windows image in a (WIM) file or virtual hard disk (VHD) file, about the images contained in a specific WIM or VHD file, and about mounted WIM or VHD files.
segment.target: You can use image commands to list the information about a specific Windows image in a (WIM) file or virtual hard disk (VHD) file, about the images contained in a specific WIM or VHD file, and about mounted WIM or VHD files.

segment.source: This information can help you identify mount locations, image names, or verify the architecture of the image that you are mounting.
segment.target: This information can help you identify mount locations, image names, or verify the architecture of the image that you are mounting.

segment.source: You can gather information about all of the images in a WIM or VHD file by using the /Get-ImageInfo servicing command in DISM.
segment.target: You can gather information about all of the images in a WIM or VHD file by using the /Get-ImageInfo servicing command in DISM.

segment.source: You can also gather information about a specific image in a WIM or VHD file, such as operating system, architecture, and settings, by specifying the name or index number of the image.
segment.target: You can also gather information about a specific image in a WIM or VHD file, such as operating system, architecture, and settings, by specifying the name or index number of the image.

segment.source: To specify the image in a VHD file, you must use /Index:1 .
segment.target: To specify the image in a VHD file, you must use /Index:1 .

segment.source: You can identify the images that are currently mounted on your computer, and you can list information about the mounted image such as read/write permissions, mount location, mounted file path, and mounted image index by using the /Get-MountedImageInfo servicing command.
segment.target: You can identify the images that are currently mounted on your computer, and you can list information about the mounted image such as read/write permissions, mount location, mounted file path, and mounted image index by using the /Get-MountedImageInfo servicing command.

segment.source: For more information about image commands available in DISM, see DISM - Deployment Image Servicing and Management Technical Reference for Windows.
segment.target: For more information about image commands available in DISM, see DISM - Deployment Image Servicing and Management Technical Reference for Windows.

segment.source: To list images that are contained in a WIM or VHD file
segment.target: To list images that are contained in a WIM or VHD file

segment.source: Right-click Deployment and Imaging Tools Environment and then select Run as administrator.
segment.target: Right-click Deployment and Imaging Tools Environment and then select Run as administrator.

segment.source: To list information about all of the images in a WIM or VHD file, at the elevated command prompt, type:
segment.target: To list information about all of the images in a WIM or VHD file, at the elevated command prompt, type:

segment.source: When used with the /Index or /Name options, more detailed information about the specified image is displayed.
segment.target: When used with the /Index or /Name options, more detailed information about the specified image is displayed.

segment.source: To specify the image in a VHD file, you must use .
segment.target: To specify the image in a VHD file, you must use .

segment.source: The report that is generated includes the following information.
segment.target: The report that is generated includes the following information.

segment.source: The index value of the image in the WIM or VHD file.
segment.target: The index value of the image in the WIM or VHD file.

segment.source: The Windows edition name of the image in the WIM or VHD file.
segment.target: The Windows edition name of the image in the WIM or VHD file.

segment.source: The description of the image in the WIM or VHD file.
segment.target: The description of the image in the WIM or VHD file.

segment.source: Right-click Deployment and Imaging Tools Environment and then select Run as administrator.
segment.target: Right-click Deployment and Imaging Tools Environment and then select Run as administrator.

segment.source: At the elevated command prompt, type:
segment.target: At the elevated command prompt, type:

segment.source: The report generated includes the following information:
segment.target: The report generated includes the following information:

segment.source: The location where the image is mounted.
segment.target: The location where the image is mounted.

segment.source: The full path to the WIM or VHD file.
segment.target: The full path to the WIM or VHD file.

segment.source: The index number of the mounted image that is enclosed in WIM or VHD file.
segment.target: The index number of the mounted image that is enclosed in WIM or VHD file.

segment.source: Yes if the mounted image allows for both read and write access or No if the mounted image allows for read-only access only.
segment.target: Yes if the mounted image allows for both read and write access or No if the mounted image allows for read-only access only.

segment.source: The mount status of the image.
segment.target: The mount status of the image.

segment.source: The possible values include the following:
segment.target: The possible values include the following:

segment.source: This can be caused by rebooting the host system when the image is mounted.
segment.target: This can be caused by rebooting the host system when the image is mounted.

segment.source: Invalid.: the image is in an invalid state.
segment.target: Invalid.: the image is in an invalid state.

segment.source: You might have to use /Cleanup-Mountpoints on the image.
segment.target: You might have to use /Cleanup-Mountpoints on the image.

segment.source: You can mount a Windows Preinstallation Environment (Windows PE) image for servicing in the same way you would any Windows image.
segment.target: You can mount a Windows Preinstallation Environment (Windows PE) image for servicing in the same way you would any Windows image.

segment.source: There are also Windows PE servicing commands that are specific to a Windows PE image.
segment.target: There are also Windows PE servicing commands that are specific to a Windows PE image.

segment.source: These commands can be used to list Windows PE settings such as scratchspace, targetpath, and profiling information.
segment.target: These commands can be used to list Windows PE settings such as scratchspace, targetpath, and profiling information.

segment.source: For more information about Windows PE servicing commands available in DISM, see DISM Windows PE Servicing Command-Line Options.
segment.target: For more information about Windows PE servicing commands available in DISM, see DISM Windows PE Servicing Command-Line Options.

segment.source: To list all settings in the mounted Windows PE image.
segment.target: To list all settings in the mounted Windows PE image.

segment.source: Right-click Deployment and Imaging Tools Environment and then select Run as administrator.
segment.target: Right-click Deployment and Imaging Tools Environment and then select Run as administrator.

segment.source: To list information about all of the Windows PE settings in the mounted Windows PE image, at the elevated command prompt, type:
segment.target: To list information about all of the Windows PE settings in the mounted Windows PE image, at the elevated command prompt, type:

segment.source: The report generated includes the following information:
segment.target: The report generated includes the following information:

segment.source: Reports whether Windows PE profiling is enabled or disabled.
segment.target: Reports whether Windows PE profiling is enabled or disabled.

segment.source: The amount of writeable space available on the Windows PE system volume when booted in ramdisk mode.
segment.target: The amount of writeable space available on the Windows PE system volume when booted in ramdisk mode.

segment.source: The path to the root of the Windows PE image at boot time.
segment.target: The path to the root of the Windows PE image at boot time.

segment.source: The driver-servicing commands can be used to enumerate driver packages in the driver store based on their .inf files.
segment.target: The driver-servicing commands can be used to enumerate driver packages in the driver store based on their .inf files.

segment.source: You can use the /Get commands to display basic information about third-party driver packages or all driver packages in the offline image.
segment.target: You can use the /Get commands to display basic information about third-party driver packages or all driver packages in the offline image.

segment.source: When you point to an offline image or a running operating system, you can determine what driver packages are in the image, and get information about the drivers.
segment.target: When you point to an offline image or a running operating system, you can determine what driver packages are in the image, and get information about the drivers.

segment.source: You can display detailed information about a specific installed .inf file, or one that is not yet installed.
segment.target: You can display detailed information about a specific installed .inf file, or one that is not yet installed.

segment.source: Installed drivers in the driver store will be named Oem0.inf, Oem1.inf, and so on.
segment.target: Installed drivers in the driver store will be named Oem0.inf, Oem1.inf, and so on.

segment.source: For more information about driver-servicing commands available in DISM, see DISM Driver Servicing Command-Line Options.
segment.target: For more information about driver-servicing commands available in DISM, see DISM Driver Servicing Command-Line Options.

segment.source: To list driver packages in the offline image
segment.target: To list driver packages in the offline image

segment.source: Right-click Deployment and Imaging Tools Environment and then select Run as administrator.
segment.target: Right-click Deployment and Imaging Tools Environment and then select Run as administrator.

segment.source: Use one of the following commands to list information about all of the driver packages in a mounted offline Windows image:
segment.target: Use one of the following commands to list information about all of the driver packages in a mounted offline Windows image:

segment.source: For a running operating system, type one of the following commands:
segment.target: For a running operating system, type one of the following commands:

segment.source: The report generated includes the following information:
segment.target: The report generated includes the following information:

segment.source: The name of the driver package after it is added to the driver store.
segment.target: The name of the driver package after it is added to the driver store.

segment.source: The original .inf file name of the driver package.
segment.target: The original .inf file name of the driver package.

segment.source: Yes for a default driver (inbox driver) or No for third-party driver packages.
segment.target: Yes for a default driver (inbox driver) or No for third-party driver packages.

segment.source: The friendly name of the device class the driver is a member of.
segment.target: The friendly name of the device class the driver is a member of.

segment.source: The provider or digital signature for the driver package.
segment.target: The provider or digital signature for the driver package.

segment.source: The date associated with the driver, as it is specified in the .inf file.
segment.target: The date associated with the driver, as it is specified in the .inf file.

segment.source: The date will be formatted appropriately for your locale.
segment.target: The date will be formatted appropriately for your locale.

segment.source: The version number that is specified in the INF driverVer directive.
segment.target: The version number that is specified in the INF driverVer directive.

segment.source: To get information about a specific driver
segment.target: To get information about a specific driver

segment.source: Right-click Deployment and Imaging Tools Environment and then select Run as administrator.
segment.target: Right-click Deployment and Imaging Tools Environment and then select Run as administrator.

segment.source: List information about a specific driver package in the offline Windows image.
segment.target: List information about a specific driver package in the offline Windows image.

segment.source: For a running operating system, type:
segment.target: For a running operating system, type:

segment.source: The report generated includes the following information:
segment.target: The report generated includes the following information:

segment.source: The name of the driver package after it is added to the driver store.
segment.target: The name of the driver package after it is added to the driver store.

segment.source: The path to the driver location.
segment.target: The path to the driver location.

segment.source: If the driver is installed, the path to the driver store is listed.
segment.target: If the driver is installed, the path to the driver store is listed.

segment.source: If the driver is not installed yet, the path to the driver on the servicing host is listed.
segment.target: If the driver is not installed yet, the path to the driver on the servicing host is listed.

segment.source: The friendly name of the device class the driver is a member of.
segment.target: The friendly name of the device class the driver is a member of.

segment.source: The description of the device class the driver is a member of.
segment.target: The description of the device class the driver is a member of.

segment.source: The GUID of the device class that the driver is a member of.
segment.target: The GUID of the device class that the driver is a member of.

segment.source: The date associated with the driver, as it is specified in the .inf file.
segment.target: The date associated with the driver, as it is specified in the .inf file.

segment.source: The date will be formatted appropriately for your locale.
segment.target: The date will be formatted appropriately for your locale.

segment.source: The driver version number that is specified in the INF driverVer directive.
segment.target: The driver version number that is specified in the INF driverVer directive.

segment.source: Yes if the driver is boot critical or No if it is not.
segment.target: Yes if the driver is boot critical or No if it is not.

segment.source: The architecture of the image that it is installed on.
segment.target: The architecture of the image that it is installed on.

segment.source: If the driver is not installed yet, the field is reported repeatedly for each supported operating system architecture.
segment.target: If the driver is not installed yet, the field is reported repeatedly for each supported operating system architecture.

segment.source: The manufacturer of the supported device.
segment.target: The manufacturer of the supported device.

segment.source: A description of the supported device.
segment.target: A description of the supported device.

segment.source: The hardware ID of the supported device.
segment.target: The hardware ID of the supported device.

segment.source: The service name of the driver.
segment.target: The service name of the driver.

segment.source: Alternate Plug and Play (PnP) IDs for the device, if any apply.
segment.target: Alternate Plug and Play (PnP) IDs for the device, if any apply.

segment.source: PnP IDs that will not match the device, any apply.
segment.target: PnP IDs that will not match the device, any apply.

segment.source: If you point to a driver that is not yet installed, the report will be slightly different.
segment.target: If you point to a driver that is not yet installed, the report will be slightly different.

segment.source: You can use operating system package-servicing commands to obtain information about Windows packages.
segment.target: You can use operating system package-servicing commands to obtain information about Windows packages.

segment.source: You can also use DISM and package-servicing commands to obtain information about Windows features, either offline or on a running Windows installation.
segment.target: You can also use DISM and package-servicing commands to obtain information about Windows features, either offline or on a running Windows installation.

segment.source: You can use the /PackagePath option to specify a .cab file or a folder where the .cab file is extracted.
segment.target: You can use the /PackagePath option to specify a .cab file or a folder where the .cab file is extracted.

segment.source: You cannot use this command to obtain package information for .msu files.
segment.target: You cannot use this command to obtain package information for .msu files.

segment.source: Alternately, you can use /Get-Packages to find the name of a package, and then use /PackageName to specify the name of the package.
segment.target: Alternately, you can use /Get-Packages to find the name of a package, and then use /PackageName to specify the name of the package.

segment.source: You can display detailed information about a feature.
segment.target: You can display detailed information about a feature.

segment.source: You must use the /FeatureName option with the /Get command.
segment.target: You must use the /FeatureName option with the /Get command.

segment.source: Use the /Get-Features option to find the name of the feature in the image.
segment.target: Use the /Get-Features option to find the name of the feature in the image.

segment.source: Feature names are case sensitive if you are servicing a Windows image other than Windows 8.
segment.target: Feature names are case sensitive if you are servicing a Windows image other than Windows 8.

segment.source: For more information about operating system package-servicing commands available in DISM, see DISM Operating System Package Servicing Command-Line Options.
segment.target: For more information about operating system package-servicing commands available in DISM, see DISM Operating System Package Servicing Command-Line Options.

segment.source: To list all packages in the image
segment.target: To list all packages in the image

segment.source: Right-click Deployment and Imaging Tools Environment and then select Run as administrator.
segment.target: Right-click Deployment and Imaging Tools Environment and then select Run as administrator.

segment.target: To list information about all of the packages in the offline Windows image, type the following command:

segment.target: For a running operating system, type the following command:

segment.source: The report generated includes the following information:
segment.target: The report generated includes the following information:

segment.source: The name of the package as it appears in the image.
segment.target: The name of the package as it appears in the image.

segment.source: The current state of the package.
segment.target: The current state of the package.

segment.source: The package is installed but requires a reboot to complete the pending online actions.
segment.target: The package is installed but requires a reboot to complete the pending online actions.

segment.source: The package is staged for installation.
segment.target: The package is staged for installation.

segment.source: The type of package that it is.
segment.target: The type of package that it is.

segment.source: A Windows operating system Language pack or Language Interface Pack (LIP).
segment.target: A Windows operating system Language pack or Language Interface Pack (LIP).

segment.source: Core operating system components including optional features.
segment.target: Core operating system components including optional features.

segment.source: The UTC date and time when the installation occurred.
segment.target: The UTC date and time when the installation occurred.

segment.source: If the package is not installed yet, the Install Time field is left blank.
segment.target: If the package is not installed yet, the Install Time field is left blank.

segment.source: To list information about a specific package
segment.target: To list information about a specific package

segment.source: Right-click Deployment and Imaging Tools Environment and then select Run as administrator.
segment.target: Right-click Deployment and Imaging Tools Environment and then select Run as administrator.

segment.source: To list information about a specific package in the offline Windows image, type one of the following commands:
segment.target: To list information about a specific package in the offline Windows image, type one of the following commands:

segment.target: The report generated includes the following information:

segment.source: The name of the package as it appears in the image.
segment.target: The name of the package as it appears in the image.

segment.source: Indicates if the package applies to the image.
segment.target: Indicates if the package applies to the image.

segment.source: The company that provided the package, if available.
segment.target: The company that provided the package, if available.

segment.source: The date and time the package was created, if available.
segment.target: The date and time the package was created, if available.

segment.source: A brief description of the package.
segment.target: A brief description of the package.

segment.source: The client tool that installed the package.
segment.target: The client tool that installed the package.

segment.source: The date and time the package was installed.
segment.target: The date and time the package was installed.

segment.source: If the package is not installed yet, the Install Time field is left blank.
segment.target: If the package is not installed yet, the Install Time field is left blank.

segment.source: The date the package was last updated, if available.
segment.target: The date the package was last updated, if available.

segment.source: The display name of the package, localized if available.
segment.target: The display name of the package, localized if available.

segment.source: Generally, default will be displayed for all servicing packages.
segment.target: Generally, default will be displayed for all servicing packages.

segment.source: The name of the product that the package belongs to, if available.
segment.target: The name of the product that the package belongs to, if available.

segment.source: The version of the product that the package belongs to, if available.
segment.target: The version of the product that the package belongs to, if available.

segment.source: The type of package that it is.
segment.target: The type of package that it is.

segment.source: A Windows operating system Language pack or Language Interface Pack (LIP).
segment.target: A Windows operating system Language pack or Language Interface Pack (LIP).

segment.source: Core operating system components including optional features.
segment.target: Core operating system components including optional features.

segment.source: Indicates if a reboot is required when you install or uninstall the package online.
segment.target: Indicates if a reboot is required when you install or uninstall the package online.

segment.source: Where to find support information, if available.
segment.target: Where to find support information, if available.

segment.source: Indicates if the package is installed in the operating system.
segment.target: Indicates if the package is installed in the operating system.

segment.source: The package will be installed but requires a reboot to complete pending online actions.
segment.target: The package will be installed but requires a reboot to complete pending online actions.

segment.source: The package is staged for installation.
segment.target: The package is staged for installation.

segment.source: The package can be installed offline without booting the image.
segment.target: The package can be installed offline without booting the image.

segment.source: You must boot into the image in order to complete installation of this package.
segment.target: You must boot into the image in order to complete installation of this package.

segment.source: You may have to boot into the image in order to complete the installation of this package.
segment.target: You may have to boot into the image in order to complete the installation of this package.

segment.source: Many packages can be installed offline entirely.
segment.target: Many packages can be installed offline entirely.

segment.source: If you attempt to install a package offline and a reboot is required, it will be reported in the log file.
segment.target: If you attempt to install a package offline and a reboot is required, it will be reported in the log file.

segment.source: You can check the status of a package using the Get-PackageInfo command.
segment.target: You can check the status of a package using the Get-PackageInfo command.

segment.source: This field is only applicable to Windows 8, Windows Server® 2012, and Windows Preinstallation Environment (Windows PE) 4.0 target images.
segment.target: This field is only applicable to Windows 8, Windows Server® 2012, and Windows Preinstallation Environment (Windows PE) 4.0 target images.

segment.source: A list of custom properties defined in the package manifest file.
segment.target: A list of custom properties defined in the package manifest file.

segment.source: If there are no custom properties, (No custom properties found) will be displayed.
segment.target: If there are no custom properties, (No custom properties found) will be displayed.

segment.source: A list of the features found in the package.
segment.target: A list of the features found in the package.

segment.source: If there is no feature in the package, the package identity will be displayed followed by (No features found for this package).
segment.target: If there is no feature in the package, the package identity will be displayed followed by (No features found for this package).

segment.source: You can use the app package (.appx) servicing commands to list the provisioned apps in a Windows image.
segment.target: You can use the app package (.appx) servicing commands to list the provisioned apps in a Windows image.

segment.source: Provisioned apps will be registered for every user profile that is created for the Windows image.
segment.target: Provisioned apps will be registered for every user profile that is created for the Windows image.

segment.source: For more information about app package servicing commands available in DISM, see DISM App Package (.appx or .appxbundle) Servicing Command-Line Options.
segment.target: For more information about app package servicing commands available in DISM, see DISM App Package (.appx or .appxbundle) Servicing Command-Line Options.

segment.source: The international servicing commands can be used to query existing international settings in Windows and Windows PE images.
segment.target: The international servicing commands can be used to query existing international settings in Windows and Windows PE images.

segment.source: For more information about operating system package-servicing commands available in DISM, see DISM Languages and International Servicing Command-Line Options.
segment.target: For more information about operating system package-servicing commands available in DISM, see DISM Languages and International Servicing Command-Line Options.

segment.source: International servicing commands cannot be used on a Windows Vista or Windows Server 2008 image.
segment.target: International servicing commands cannot be used on a Windows Vista or Windows Server 2008 image.

segment.source: Use the /online option to display information about international settings and languages in the running operating system.
segment.target: Use the /online option to display information about international settings and languages in the running operating system.

segment.source: Use /image:pathtoofflineimagedirectory to display information about international settings and languages in the offline image.
segment.target: Use /image:pathtoofflineimagedirectory to display information about international settings and languages in the offline image.

segment.source: When used with the /image and /distribution options, information about international settings and languages in the distribution is displayed.
segment.target: When used with the /image and /distribution options, information about international settings and languages in the distribution is displayed.

segment.source: To list all international settings and languages
segment.target: To list all international settings and languages

segment.source: Right-click Deployment and Imaging Tools Environment and then select Run as administrator.
segment.target: Right-click Deployment and Imaging Tools Environment and then select Run as administrator.

segment.source: To list information about all of the international settings in the offline Windows image, type one of the following commands:
segment.target: To list information about all of the international settings in the offline Windows image, type one of the following commands:

segment.source: For a running operating system, type the following command:
segment.target: For a running operating system, type the following command:

segment.source: The report generated includes the following information:
segment.target: The report generated includes the following information:

segment.source: The language that is currently set as the default system UI language.
segment.target: The language that is currently set as the default system UI language.

segment.source: The language for non-Unicode programs (also referred to as system locale) and font settings.
segment.target: The language for non-Unicode programs (also referred to as system locale) and font settings.

segment.source: The time zone that is currently set as the default.
segment.target: The time zone that is currently set as the default.

segment.source: The standards and formats language (also referred to as user locale) that is set for the default user.
segment.target: The standards and formats language (also referred to as user locale) that is set for the default user.

segment.source: The geographical location that is currently set for the operating system.
segment.target: The geographical location that is currently set for the operating system.

segment.source: For more information about geographical locations, see Table of Geographical Locations.
segment.target: For more information about geographical locations, see Table of Geographical Locations.

segment.source: The value pair for the active keyboard.
segment.target: The value pair for the active keyboard.

segment.source: In the example provided, 0409 is the language identifier and 00000409 is the keyboard identifier.
segment.target: In the example provided, 0409 is the language identifier and 00000409 is the keyboard identifier.

segment.source: The value pair for the default keyboard.
segment.target: The value pair for the default keyboard.

segment.source: In the example provided, 0409 is the language identifier and 00000409 is the keyboard identifier.
segment.target: In the example provided, 0409 is the language identifier and 00000409 is the keyboard identifier.

segment.source: A list of all installed language packs.
segment.target: A list of all installed language packs.

segment.source: The type of each installed language pack.
segment.target: The type of each installed language pack.

segment.source: For more information, see Add Language Packs to Windows.
segment.target: For more information, see Add Language Packs to Windows.

segment.source: Type: Partially localized language, MUI type
segment.target: Type: Partially localized language, MUI type

segment.source: A list of the languages that are available in the distribution share.
segment.target: A list of the languages that are available in the distribution share.

segment.source: This list includes the name of the folder in the distribution share.
segment.target: This list includes the name of the folder in the distribution share.

segment.source: The language of the actual LP.cab file in the folder is not validated.
segment.target: The language of the actual LP.cab file in the folder is not validated.

segment.source: For example, if the path to the distribution is …\Langpacks\bg-BG\Lp.cab, the value of bg-BG will be reported as the language in the distribution share even if the LP.cab file is not the correct .cab file for bg-BG.
segment.target: For example, if the path to the distribution is …\Langpacks\bg-BG\Lp.cab, the value of bg-BG will be reported as the language in the distribution share even if the LP.cab file is not the correct .cab file for bg-BG.

segment.source: The default language in the distribution is: ja-JP
segment.target: The default language in the distribution is: ja-JP

segment.source: The other available languages in the distribution are: bg-BG, nl-NL
segment.target: The other available languages in the distribution are: bg-BG, nl-NL

segment.source: A list of the keyboard drivers for Japanese or Korean keyboards, if any are installed.
segment.target: A list of the keyboard drivers for Japanese or Korean keyboards, if any are installed.

segment.source: You can use the edition-servicing commands to obtain information about which editions of Windows are available for upgrade.
segment.target: You can use the edition-servicing commands to obtain information about which editions of Windows are available for upgrade.

segment.source: Target editions are the editions of Windows that you can upgrade to.
segment.target: Target editions are the editions of Windows that you can upgrade to.

segment.source: You can display information about the current edition or the target edition of an offline Windows image or a running operating system.
segment.target: You can display information about the current edition or the target edition of an offline Windows image or a running operating system.

segment.source: For more information about Windows edition servicing commands available in DISM, see DISM Windows Edition-Servicing Command-Line Options.
segment.target: For more information about Windows edition servicing commands available in DISM, see DISM Windows Edition-Servicing Command-Line Options.

segment.source: To get information about the current Windows editions
segment.target: To get information about the current Windows editions

segment.source: Right-click Deployment and Imaging Tools Environment and then select Run as administrator.
segment.target: Right-click Deployment and Imaging Tools Environment and then select Run as administrator.

segment.source: To list information about the current edition of the offline Windows image, type the following command:
segment.target: To list information about the current edition of the offline Windows image, type the following command:

segment.source: For a running operating system, type the following command:
segment.target: For a running operating system, type the following command:

segment.source: To get information about target editions of Windows
segment.target: To get information about target editions of Windows

segment.source: Right-click Deployment and Imaging Tools Environment and then select Run as administrator.
segment.target: Right-click Deployment and Imaging Tools Environment and then select Run as administrator.

segment.source: To list information about the target edition of the offline Windows image, type the following command:
segment.target: To list information about the target edition of the offline Windows image, type the following command:

segment.source: For a running operating system, type the following command:
segment.target: For a running operating system, type the following command:

segment.source: Application servicing command-line options can be used on a offline image to check the applicability of Microsoft® Windows® Installer application patches (.msp files) and to query your offline image for information about installed Windows Installer applications (.msi files) and application patches (.msp files).
segment.target: Application servicing command-line options can be used on a offline image to check the applicability of Microsoft® Windows® Installer application patches (.msp files) and to query your offline image for information about installed Windows Installer applications (.msi files) and application patches (.msp files).

segment.source: You can display detailed information about installed MSP patches filtered by patch and application.
segment.target: You can display detailed information about installed MSP patches filtered by patch and application.

segment.source: If the /PatchCode option is specified, detailed information is displayed for all Windows Installer applications that the patch is applied to.
segment.target: If the /PatchCode option is specified, detailed information is displayed for all Windows Installer applications that the patch is applied to.

segment.source: If the /ProductCode option is specified, information about all MSP patches in the specified application is displayed.
segment.target: If the /ProductCode option is specified, information about all MSP patches in the specified application is displayed.

segment.source: If the /PatchCode and /ProductCode options are both specified, information is displayed only if that specific patch is applied to the specified Windows Installer application.
segment.target: If the /PatchCode and /ProductCode options are both specified, information is displayed only if that specific patch is applied to the specified Windows Installer application.

segment.source: If the /PatchCode and /ProductCode options are not specified, all installed Windows Installer packages and MSP patches are displayed.
segment.target: If the /PatchCode and /ProductCode options are not specified, all installed Windows Installer packages and MSP patches are displayed.

segment.source: For more information about application servicing commands available in DISM, see DISM Application Servicing Command-Line Options.
segment.target: For more information about application servicing commands available in DISM, see DISM Application Servicing Command-Line Options.

segment.source: To list information about installed MSP patches
segment.target: To list information about installed MSP patches

segment.source: Right-click Deployment and Imaging Tools Environment and then select Run as administrator.
segment.target: Right-click Deployment and Imaging Tools Environment and then select Run as administrator.

segment.source: To list information about the MSP patches, type one of the following commands:
segment.target: To list information about the MSP patches, type one of the following commands:

segment.source: The report generated includes the following information:
segment.target: The report generated includes the following information:

segment.source: A GUID identifying a specific Windows Installer package.
segment.target: A GUID identifying a specific Windows Installer package.

segment.source: The package code associates an .msi file together with an application or product and can also be used for the verification of sources.
segment.target: The package code associates an .msi file together with an application or product and can also be used for the verification of sources.

segment.source: A GUID that is the principal identification of an application or product.
segment.target: A GUID that is the principal identification of an application or product.

segment.source: The registered display name for the patch.
segment.target: The registered display name for the patch.

segment.source: For patches that do not include the DisplayName property in the MsiPatchMetadata table, the returned display name is an empty string.
segment.target: For patches that do not include the DisplayName property in the MsiPatchMetadata table, the returned display name is an empty string.

segment.source: 1 if this patch is currently applied to the product.
segment.target: 1 if this patch is currently applied to the product.

segment.source: 2 if this patch has been superseded by another patch.
segment.target: 2 if this patch has been superseded by another patch.

segment.source: 4 if this patch has been made obsolete by another patch.
segment.target: 4 if this patch has been made obsolete by another patch.

segment.source: 1 if the patch is marked as possible to uninstall from the product.
segment.target: 1 if the patch is marked as possible to uninstall from the product.

segment.source: In this case, the installer can still block the uninstallation if this patch is required by another patch that cannot be uninstalled.
segment.target: In this case, the installer can still block the uninstallation if this patch is required by another patch that cannot be uninstalled.

segment.source: Where to find support information, if available.
segment.target: Where to find support information, if available.

segment.source: The set of patch transforms applied to the product by the last patch installation.
segment.target: The set of patch transforms applied to the product by the last patch installation.

segment.source: This value may not be available for per-user unmanaged applications if the user is not logged on to the computer.
segment.target: This value may not be available for per-user unmanaged applications if the user is not logged on to the computer.

segment.source: The location of the local cached patch file that is used by the product.
segment.target: The location of the local cached patch file that is used by the product.

segment.source: The date when the patch was applied to the product.
segment.target: The date when the patch was applied to the product.

segment.source: To list information about MSP patches applied to an application
segment.target: To list information about MSP patches applied to an application

segment.source: Right-click Deployment and Imaging Tools Environment and then select Run as administrator.
segment.target: Right-click Deployment and Imaging Tools Environment and then select Run as administrator.

segment.source: To list information about the MSP patches, type one of the following commands:
segment.target: To list information about the MSP patches, type one of the following commands:

segment.source: The report generated includes the following information:
segment.target: The report generated includes the following information:

segment.source: A GUID identifying a particular Windows Installer package.
segment.target: A GUID identifying a particular Windows Installer package.

segment.source: The package code associates an .msi file together with an application or product and can also be used for the verification of sources.
segment.target: The package code associates an .msi file together with an application or product and can also be used for the verification of sources.

segment.source: A GUID that is the principal identification of an application or product.
segment.target: A GUID that is the principal identification of an application or product.

segment.source: The registered display name for the patch.
segment.target: The registered display name for the patch.

segment.source: For patches that do not include the DisplayName property in the MsiPatchMetadata table, the returned display name is an empty string.
segment.target: For patches that do not include the DisplayName property in the MsiPatchMetadata table, the returned display name is an empty string.

segment.source: To list information about all Windows Installer applications
segment.target: To list information about all Windows Installer applications

segment.source: Right-click Deployment and Imaging Tools Environment and then select Run as administrator.
segment.target: Right-click Deployment and Imaging Tools Environment and then select Run as administrator.

segment.source: To list information about the MSP patches, type the following command:
segment.target: To list information about the MSP patches, type the following command:

segment.source: The report generated lists the product code and product name for applications that are installed in the offline image.
segment.target: The report generated lists the product code and product name for applications that are installed in the offline image.

segment.source: To list information about a specific Windows Installer application
segment.target: To list information about a specific Windows Installer application

segment.source: Right-click Deployment and Imaging Tools Environment and then select Run as administrator.
segment.target: Right-click Deployment and Imaging Tools Environment and then select Run as administrator.

segment.source: To list information about the MSP patches, type the following command:
segment.target: To list information about the MSP patches, type the following command:

segment.source: The report generated includes the following information:
segment.target: The report generated includes the following information:

segment.source: A GUID that is the principal identification of an application or product.
segment.target: A GUID that is the principal identification of an application or product.

segment.source: The installation state for the product at initialization.
segment.target: The installation state for the product at initialization.

segment.source: -1 if the product is neither advertised nor installed.
segment.target: -1 if the product is neither advertised nor installed.

segment.source: 1 if the product is advertised but not installed.
segment.target: 1 if the product is advertised but not installed.

segment.source: 2 if the product is installed for a different user.
segment.target: 2 if the product is installed for a different user.

segment.source: 5 if the product is installed for the current user.
segment.target: 5 if the product is installed for the current user.

segment.source: A GUID identifying a particular Windows Installer package.
segment.target: A GUID identifying a particular Windows Installer package.

segment.source: The package code associates an .msi file together with an application or product and can also be used for the verification of sources.
segment.target: The package code associates an .msi file together with an application or product and can also be used for the verification of sources.

segment.source: The version of the product in string format.
segment.target: The version of the product in string format.

segment.source: 0 if the product is advertised or installed per-user.
segment.target: 0 if the product is advertised or installed per-user.

segment.source: 1 if the product is advertised or installed per-computer for all users.
segment.target: 1 if the product is advertised or installed per-computer for all users.

segment.source: The name of the manufacturer for the product.
segment.target: The name of the manufacturer for the product.

segment.source: The decimal identifier for the product language.
segment.target: The decimal identifier for the product language.

segment.source: The directory that contains the source .cab file or the source file tree of the installation package.
segment.target: The directory that contains the source .cab file or the source file tree of the installation package.

segment.source: The name of the original installation package.
segment.target: The name of the original installation package.

segment.source: Where to find support information, if available.
segment.target: Where to find support information, if available.

segment.source: The set of patch transforms applied to the product by the last patch installation.
segment.target: The set of patch transforms applied to the product by the last patch installation.

segment.source: This value may not be available for per-user unmanaged applications if the user is not logged on to the computer.
segment.target: This value may not be available for per-user unmanaged applications if the user is not logged on to the computer.

segment.source: The location of the local cached package.
segment.target: The location of the local cached package.

segment.source: The date the application was installed.
segment.target: The date the application was installed.
